												Really not what I would describe as a game, I think "meditation" comes closer.  While at first it seems like this is just moving wallpaper, the pond will become sick without your intervention.  There is a careful balance that needs to be maintained. If there are too many predators, they will eat all the small fish and then eventually starve. Without bottom feeders dangerous toxins will start to build up and you can watch as they travel up the food chain.  This environment really pulls you into the ebb and flow of the pond's ecosystem without being too stressful. I found Among Ripples to be a great way to unwind and take my mind off of other things. I also loved the watercolor art style. The music dose get a bit repetitive after a while, but it was innocuous enough not to be too annoying. Still, some more verity in the music would be nice. I think the game could also be expanded with different ecosystems; perhaps a saltwater tide-pool or tropical river. For a free game, I think it dose really well though.

												First of all, I would like to say that this game is good. Not great, but pretty good in the sense that this is a cool idea with a bit of potential to it. I really like the cut-out and painted art style that strikingly reminds me of the children's picture books that I used to read all the time when I was little. Technically, the mechanics of the game are simple: click on certain objects and spaces in the pond and different animals will spawn. Though not entirely clear, I think the premise is to get the ecosystem of the pond to take care of itself as you try to repair it and get it back on it's feet again, so to speak. Then basically the rest of the time, you're monitoring the ponds inhabitants as they're born, eaten, or die from old age. I notice that the longer they stay in the pond, they're skin textures change (which is, I assume, is them aging...?) Another thing I started to notice is that there are many things that happen that the game doesn't tell you about, which gives some people, like me, the urge to figure it out. For example, what is the darkened haze that starts to rise in the background that starts from the bottom of the pond? Is it a good or a bad thing? I've tried several attempts to get it to raise it higher, but wasn't sure how to keep it that way. I digress, though... Even though this game isn't as complex as they advertise it to be, I have the feeling that it has the potential to become that way. And as people below in the reviews say that it's just relaxation simulator, or what have you, I still think there's more to the game than that. Not only that, IT'S FREE! So good on you, developer. I would like to see this expanded, and even play some of your future creations, if possible.

Among Ripples is an artistic ecological simulator. Help a pond maintain a delicate balance with its aquatic population as you add additional specimen to it while keeping in check and limiting predators versus their preys.Pros: It takes no time getting started when beginning a new game, compensating for the lack of a save feature. The game is very soothing, the music being calm and the background having all the appearances of hand painting. Seasons cycle as the canvas switches from shades of greens, to yellows, reds and pinks. The animals grow and their textures and shapes (length, width) change depending on what they eat. The pond's ecosystem affect its ecology, and you'll see it ever changing as you regularly reintroduce species to readjust the balance in hope of making it self-sustaining for as long as possible, the challenge being not in keeping every species fed, but on keeping the preys numerous enough to reproduce at an equal or faster rate that they are killed. The beauty of this is that it's a self-determining goal, as the game itself doesn't hold any score or give any objectives out right.Cons: The quantity of species is fairly limited, and maintaining each isn't ultimately required, as animals often have alternative method of feeding. The music is limited to a single track that plays over and over again. It's not an annoying song by any means, but having a small variety from game to game would be appreciated, perhaps the same for the background canvas which you entirely ignore and forget it's there to see after a short while playing.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!I'm actually surprised at how much I will recommend this game. It's not for everyone, of course, but it's as legit a casual game as any solitary games out there, except for how calming and relaxing it feels when playing. I'd meditate to that type of music! Oh, and it's free.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

												I am stating that I recommend this game with a caveats as a lot of people don't seem to get the point.- This is a game in only the loosest sense of the word. It IS actually a game, but it requires a great deal of patience(not only to play, but to understand it), and no score is kept. - This game is NOT about pressing buttons. It's about pressing buttons once, and then not pressing buttons again for as long as possible.- The tutorial is kinda bad in that it really doesn't explain the game at all, it just tells you how to work the controls, not what they mean. The game part of this is about finding balance. (Sure, you could just keep spawning things, but that gets old fast.)- The Oxygen content of the water seems to control the algae growth(dace food) and how many creatures you can keep in the pond at any one time. Increase the Oxygen, slow the algae growth, but get more critters. - The basic stock are the Dace and the clam. At the lowest Oxygen levels, you can spawn 3 dace and 2 clams and have the pond run seemingly indefinitely without any other input. By adjusting the Oxygen levels and initial spawns, you can see how long the ecosystem lasts as you build it. - If you want something fast paced, this is not your game. - This is a game for after work where you just want to forget the rest of the world exists and do something mind-numbing without the stupidity of Hollywood. It's simple at the beginning, but harder the more complex you make it.

												Lookswise, “Among Ripples” reminds me of a prettied-up, "no consequences" version of "Odell Lake". If you aren't old as the wheel, fire or dirt - like me - Google it real quicklike.But where "Odell Lake" had you basically roleplaying a fish and RNG'd the outcome of your decisions on interactions with other lake critters, "Among Ripples" is an ultra-spartan point and click with a sort of mild environmental message of "Stuff affects stuff." In “Among Ripples” stuff affects stuff a little, and not permanently.TLDR Bottom line: "Among Ripples" is pretty and it's mellow. It will likely provide momentary distraction for those who find the idea of a zen nature simulator interesting, but it's free so if that is your thing - Try it. I did. But I cannot currently recommend it as anything more than a slightly interactive screensaver at this time. ---My thoughts after a whopping ~25-30 min of "Among Ripples": (And yes, the amount of time is indeed a massive expenditure for this game. Not sure why I did it except that I like nature, zen games and simulator games... and I guess I was hoping for something to happen that never did.)The paper cutout creatures and background are pretty. The backwoodsy music is mellow and somewhat enjoyable, for a brief music loop. It definitely suits the mood of this game. To "play" you click on different features in the environment and fish, clams, crawdads, etc. will spawn in specific  very limited numbers. You can further toy with the ecosystem by altering oxygen levels, and adding/not adding "cleaner" species (i.e. crawdads + clams). Again, it is "pretty" and there is a decent enough subtle environmental message, but...Begin animal nerd rant: There are things that I find weird. So, you can only spawn a certain number of critters of any given species via the clicking method. For example, you may only have one otter *ever* even though one may ponder what happens when Mr. Otter dies without having a mate-- what happens then? (NO MOAR OTTERZ!!1 That's what!! If this were more realistic...) I mean, "Why you click the reeds by the tree and spawn one new otter, of course!"I get that they are probably saying something like "only one apex predator" per x number of fish in this tiny ecosystem. I get that logic and would be fine with that chain of thoughts... if you couldn't then spawn 5-6 huge pike in the same tiny pond, but only 5 little perch and a handful of the other little fish (drawn a blank on their name) from the lakebed. Pike, especially ones bigger than an Otter, are... scary. I wouldn't wanna share a pond with one... This seems like a major - and illogical - predator/prey population imbalance in a game that seems to otherwise strictly limit your ability to throw anything off without "significant" (for this game) effort. For example, I can't click-spawn a buhjillion perch. Or tiny fish. Or clams. You know? The closer to the bottom of the pyramid critters where there should naturally be more of them to feed the larger, less populous species? No matter what, from my experience, only 5 Perch at a time can be clicked into the environment. I can, however, get some to spawn naturally via creating the ideal breeding environment for perch and not having too many predators to eat them, and having the pond stay with a reasonable amount of algae, and enough little feeder fish to eat... yadda yadda, but that does take a little time and experimentation. So... 5ish little fishes, 5ish Crawdad, 5ish+ Clams, 5 Perch, 5 HUGE PIKE and only one Otter. God forbid you spawn 2-3 Otters and see how that would affect the ecosystem. I would have been okay with only getting one Otter if I could spawn only an appropriate amount of Pike, and then again a proportional amount of Pike and the other smaller feeder fish. Or even 1 Otter, 5 Pike, but LOTS more little fish able to be spawned off the bat. I don't know how many would be perfect but 10+ (at least) for the tiny fish would feel more realistic. And those little fish often school and cluster in foliage/debris for protection, rather than spread out solo like they seem to in "Among Ripples". In my opinion, there are lots of "if/thens" which they could have followed that would allow this simulation to stand on more solid, realistic ground. But right now the ducklings are not in a row. I don't know. I guess the logic just doesn't add up for me. If you make an educational nature sim, you need the system to be logical, accurate and consistent. If you don't you are going to irk/boggle/ the people that already get how it should work and you may be misguiding the rest of the folks who don't. End Animal Nerd Rant!Okay, sorry to those who I have completely lost on by my blabbering about animals like I just did. So, "Among Ripples" is pretty... I keep saying that. Probably because after 15 minutes of play, that is all I can say. If you keep clicking on the critter spawns you will most likely have the pond stay balanced enough to be mostly healthy. It seems to take significant effort to get things gross like some of the sample images. I.e. Try to overpopulate (or at least heavily populate as best you can and then inexplicably spawn 5 hugongous Pike), don't spawn cleaner species and let the gook grow rapant while things die and rot into goo at the bottom of the algae-blooming pondy cesspit of blap. Enjoy your stripey "unhealthy" creatures and the brown, green layers in your pond. But that's it. Little effort = normalish pond ecosystem. Semi-logical effort = sick pond. Semi-logical counter-efforts = pond is normal again pretty quick. There isn't anything eventful which occurs, in either case, no sense of reward - even a sound and a message of "You have a healthy pond! Good Job!" or a health-o-meter UI indicator. It's easy enough to seemingly not ruin, ruin or unruin the pond in a flash. Maybe that is the message they are looking to send, but what they have offered here is basically 15 minutes of "pretty, clickmash, slight ponder + logical clicking and review of the mild results". After that there is very little reason to "play" this game. And I do enjoy my zen puzzles and simulator games. But "Among Ripples" is more "'Paper Graphics Revamp Odell Lake Screensaver' - Now with clicking things!". So, it is probable that I played this game longer than many would, at two bursts of ~10-15 minutes trying to see if anything INTERESTING could happen. (It doesn't) And the mellowness just isn't rewarding enough for it to hold interest. Maybe if I got a lobotomy? Anyway. My intention is not to be mean. Just realistic and apparently, long-winded. I spent more time on this review than in the game. If you got this far then maybe you can get through this free game, too!To the developers I would suggest:-More logical starter ecosystem (as described in nerdy rant)-Add ***anything*** to make the simulation more immersive/realistic, providing a point to carry on clicking for more than a fraction of an hour, rather than to leave people thinking “Well, it was free... and, uh, pretty. Yea, pretty.”i.e. Add more events/sub-events, more species, bigger environment, more environments, more actual choices and subsequent consequences. Environmental disasters - oil spills, toxic dumps, invasive exotic species, climate change, mob dumps bodies in pond... uh...i.e. ALIEN TACOS FROM SPACE CANNIBALIZE AND FISH TACOIFY ENTIRE POND POPULATIONS WHILE INADVERTENTLY SECRETING FOREIGN TOXIN THAT STARTS A WAVE OF ZOMBIE FISHES WHICH UPRISE AGAINST HUMANITY AND ANKLE BITE INFECTICATE US TO DEATHINATION!!!!1 Yea, like, anything. I dunno. I am sleepy now, and already regretting that I'm about to click "Post review" when I know I have been tiredly ranting for like 30 minutes... oh, god. -_--Best of luck to devs, and fellow gamers! content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This was a very interesting experiment in minimalism. However, it's because it is so minimalistic that Among Ripples keeps me from actually classifying it as a game. Where many games may use overly simplified graphics, art styles or gameplay mechanics in their presentation to further exemplify the underlying themes which they represent, this project focused much more on simplistic presentation for the sake of player relaxation. Simply put, Among Ripples, if it truly were a game, would be seen as an ecosystem simulator. You'll spend your time inside the game world controlling what spawns in an enclosed lake and seeing how the creatures and circumstances spawned will interact with and effect one another. It's from this choice of "gameplay" that my views on this not-a-game spawn. Beyond the very limited interaction you have with the environment, the main drawing point of this game is to wait and watch the reactions of your initial player input. In short, this is not a game because it lacks any true form of gameplay. However, what this project IS is a wonderful little way to help unwind after a stressful day. Because the only input you really have to make as the player is the initial spawning of creatures and setting of the oxygen levels in the lake, your free to observe and intervene with the happenings of the environment at your own pace. While you could actively spawn new creatures as older ones die, you are just as welcome to sit back and let the environment take care of itself, letting species spawn on their own with time and letting them interact in the same fashions they would otherwise. You may even prefer the latter, as the simplistic visuals and the calming, serene background music are a powerfully sedative combination to the stressed mind. Despite it's lack of interface with the player and it's simplistic art style, Among Ripples does actually hold an impressive amount of detail. While you control what goes on in the water, the beautifully painted forest beyond the lake changes as time passes, slowly growing orange and red and tan as summer and fall approach, building up snow bit by bit as winter falls, and having it gradually melt away as spring re-emerges. Additionally, certain combinations of circumstances can cause oddly beautiful outcomes. Leaving your lake with no mollusks to clean up pollution and algae build-up or adding too many crayfish to feed on them can result in the bottom of your lake building up with waste. Depending on the oxygen level and number of certain species in the ecosystem, this waste can have an effect on the fish that get near, spreading diseases and making them change color to sickly yellows or deep, harsh blues. This was easily the most interesting aspect of Among the Ripples for me, but in the end, as interesting as it was, I just couldn't justify it as a game. It lacks too much in intractability and there truly is no end goal to strive for. So, yes, this is not a game. In fact, you could just as easily see it as an intractable screen saver. However, it shouldn't be overlooked so easily because of that. While I can't recommend it as a fun or inspiring title to add to your expanding game libraries, I can happily vouch for this free download simply as an interesting way to help unwind after stressful periods or situations in other games. If you need a calming palate cleanser after a brutal play session in Dark Souls, Battletoads or The Impossible Game, I highly recommend you give this a try.

												Ever wanted to create and manage the eco system of a small woodland pond and its little pondy inhabitants? No, of course you haven't, no-one has. But this at least gives you the option to do just that in some small way should the mood ever take you.Among Ripples is a single screen fixed on a tiny tranquil body of water where you'll tap on various points of interest dotted along its surface to spawn fish, clams and otters then sit back and watch them swim about. When the creatures die or get eaten, tap on them again to spawn more and watch the seasons change over the course of a few minutes... that's it. That's pretty much the game in its entirety. It really feels like little more than a glorified, interactive screen saver, and unless I somehow missed some major elements of it, there's no objectives, no end game, and very little in the way of actual gameplay or interaction. But, you know what? I still kinda enjoyed it.It looks pleasant enough and has a nice calming effect, though that's mainly down to the excellent music which I could've happily let play endlessly in the background. So while there might be little to really recommend about this if I was being absolutely honest, at the same time there's pretty much nothing to complain about either, it's nice to experience for a little while, and it's free, so no-one's losing out. Posted: February 28, 2015
												First off, don't approach this as a full-priced 100% complete game, but rather a tech demo and/or prototype.You know how some of us (including me) have been kinda thumbing our noses at games that tried to be "artsy" and intentionally having zero gameplay to make some sort of point?This game is an "artsy" game done right.  It actually looks like it has some potential to get those of us who want a modicum of gameplay in these types of games interested where at the same time being accessible to those who just want to kick back and chill.You click different areas of the pond to spawn various sea life and even an otter.  Drag left/right to manipulate the amount of oxygen in the pond.  Animals grow bigger by feeding off of various things in the pond... and that's pretty much it.  Other than that they just swim around in the pond.There's no "win" condition or "endgame".  Probably will keep your interest for a few minutes.  However, I see a lot of potential for this to be turned into a full blown game.  Anyone remember El Fish from the 90s by Maxis?  I get those vibes from this game.  There's already a small bit of gameplay in it - you need to spawn clams to keep the pond clean, and the various fish you spawn can only survive depending on the amount of oxygen that's in the pond.  You have to balance this out to keep all the fish alive, else those fish die.  If those fish die, you need to use the crayfish you spawn to "clean up" the bottom of the pond.Has only one musical piece, but the art style reminds me of some other indie games I played - can't put my finger on it, but it's very easy on the eyes.  I hope they build upon this, interesting concept.

												This game, for all its simplicity, is fantastic. It's not the kind of game where you rack up lots of gameplay but it's surprisingly soothing and enjoyable.You are supposed to model the ecosystem of a small pond. Easy, right? Here's where you put some of your high school biology knowledge to work. There are clams, crayfish, an otter and three types of fish, ranging from very small to very big. You have to keep adding more creatures from the different spawn points in the pond in order to help find the right balance of critters. The pond gets dirty and the fish will die and you have to keep a mental count of the amount of critters in the pond so that they dont all eat each other at once.  I recommend that you use the tutorial first so that you know where everything is, but jumping right into the game is fun too. Try to keep more smaller animals than larger animals and mimic actual ecosystems for the most success.  It's not an extremely challenging game if you know what you're doing, and I'm sure it gets boring if you play it for too long. But the backgrounds are gorgeous and the mechanics work smoothly. What more do you want from a free game?Pros:-Great art-Smart concept-Not too difficult-Good musicCons:-May bore the truly frenetic among us

Originally posted at http://www.apochs.netAmong Ripples is the product of a student project from a two-man team that went on to form Eat Create Sleep Studios. The title, an aquatic simulator of sorts, has been receiving plenty of praise since it was first made available to download for free on-line through Google Play, Desura, and most recently Steam. But, with such an immense opportunity for the duo's debut, does this outing hold your attention, or is it an underwhelming experience?Among Ripples is a basic wildlife simulator. The ecosystem in this small pond once was able to take care of itself, but now isn't able to. The only way for life to return is with your help. You control the amount of creatures in it, including fish, crawdads, and even an otter. You can't go overboard initially though, as you are limited in having no more than five newborn species at a time. Once full grown or die off, you can throw more into the mix. You can also control the amount of air in the pond to help increase or decrease the levels of algae and other toxins within the water.And that becomes the problem right there. It's a cute idea at first, but the game has a few too many restrictions at play. There's only five aquatic types you can spawn, and an otter. Other than the air variable and uncontrollable changes in the season that can impact the ecosystem, there's nothing else to really work with. Unless you enjoy playing god over this small amount of underwater life, the novelty can wear relatively thin with what is present. Thankfully the developers do take what the community has to say into consideration, as shown by the recent update they implemented.At the time of writing this, there has been an update that allows the game to run in the background, much like the recent successful application Mountain can. However, with how fast the life typically matures, dies, or is eaten, there's very little reason to leave this program running if you are putting an effort into maintaining the environment while multi-tasking. In fact, in the time it took me to write that sentence, all but one of the fish I had in the pond died. And in writing that sentence, only two of the new ones I just hatched, along with the five clams I spawned, remain alive.Another thing I noticed is that, while the point of Among Ripples is that the pond's ecosystem can't thrive without your help, isn't necessarily true. After stepping away and letting all life die while preparing and eating dinner, I came back to find that the last remaining fish that survived was now joined by three others. Once in a while, a random fish will disappear entirely towards the bottom of the screen, but eventually, without my interference, another one or two of that species would spawn automatically. The pond hasn't exactly thrive with new life, but it can still operate on its own, but does make you interested in leaving the application running over night to see what happened while you were asleep.That said, the last thing going for Among Ripples, other than the nice hand painted visuals, ends up being the soundtrack. The ads (on Steam at least) claim it has an ambient score that changes with the seasons. After an hour of playing around with the pond and just letting it run in the background, the same loop of sombre folk music has not changed, regardless of the season I am currently facing other than getting a little louder, which is just the general progression of the music itself and not based on any other factor. As far as the ambience goes, there's very little that ends up altered other than some chirping birds in the spring and summer.In the end, Among Ripples doesn't quite live up to what it could have been, but for a student project this literal fish bowl in a pond stands as a good debut for Eat Create Sleep Studios. There are plenty of opportunities to include more species, have region-based creatures, or other detrimental and beneficial factors from the surroundings other than imminent death. Having a more realistic life span for the animals would be a nice touch as well, and not a death rate that is essentially three to four minutes in ninety percent of the spawned creatures. The good news is that the developers are listening to the community, and hopefully there will be more updates in the future, such as the most recent that included the background application function. If more is added down the line, there's no doubt it'll be a more engaging simulator. For now, it's enjoyable for what it is, and a good way to unwind after a stressful day.

												It is hard to describe this game other than it's a meditation game, but a really good one.Among Ripples Review -Detroit0127This game doesn't involve any skill (well, just the oxygen levels) and it doesn't really require any thinking at all. You deploy fish into this pond of yours and you could put a certain amount of fish in there and they swim around and interact with some calm and soothing music playing in the background.I usually write a whole big review for a game, but since it's a short but endless game (depending how you look at it, and the fact that I have legitimately played 9 hours of this game, it is actually endless) I'm going to do a pros and cons list of the game.PROS:-Free to Play (isn't that always great?)-Soothing and Calm Music (great to relax to and just listen if you don't want to play the game)-Variety of fish (you can choose what you want to put in the pond from a good amount of choices)-Seal (you can put a seal in here, he lives the longest)-Fish die... (you actually have to maintain your little pond)-Fair Graphics (doesn't really matter for this game)-Endless Gameplay (play as long as you want)-Weird But Fun (weird little game, involving fish but fun)-Relaxes you (it actually works as a meditation game!)CONS:(VERY LITTLE)-Menu (could add a few things to it, involving an option for fullscreen mode and turn down the music or completely shut it off)-Oxygen (This confused me a little bit, you have to try to get your oxygen just right to keep your fish from dying?)-Crabs (if that's what they are, they deploy things that are supposed to help but actually kill fish instead)NEUTRAL- (NEITHER GOOD NOR BAD)-Achievements (it seems like it doesn't NEED achievements, but it would be fun to have them in there)One of the coolest parts about this game is the fact that it was a school project. Obviously this would be an A+, totally worth picking up and trying! -Detroit0127
